questions.text: X-rays are best described as:
questions.explanation: X-rays are electromagnetic waves with very short wavelengths and high photon energy. They are not mechanical waves, sound waves, or particle beams.

questions.text: Which property allows X-rays to penetrate matter opaque to visible light?
questions.explanation: Penetration depth depends on photon energy. X-rays have much higher photon energy than visible light, allowing them to pass through dense materials.

questions.text: The energy of an electromagnetic wave is given by:
questions.explanation: Photon energy is inversely proportional to wavelength. Shorter wavelengths (like X-rays) correspond to higher energies.

questions.text: Compared to visible light, X-rays have:
questions.explanation: X-rays lie at much shorter wavelengths than visible light, which implies higher frequency and higher photon energy.

questions.text: X-rays were discovered by Wilhelm Röntgen in:
questions.explanation: Wilhelm Röntgen discovered X-rays in 1895, a discovery that earned him the first Nobel Prize in Physics.

questions.text: The first clinical CT scanner was introduced in:
questions.explanation: The first clinical CT scanner was introduced in 1973 by Hounsfield and Cormack.

questions.text: Which modality accounts for the highest number of examinations in German clinics?
questions.explanation: Despite newer modalities, X-ray–based imaging remains the most frequently used due to speed, cost efficiency, and availability.

questions.text: One reason X-rays remain clinically dominant is that they are:
questions.explanation: X-ray systems are fast, inexpensive, and widely available, making them ideal for routine clinical use.

questions.text: The primary biological risk of X-rays comes from:
questions.explanation: X-rays ionize atoms, which can damage DNA and potentially lead to cancer.

questions.text: Ionization can lead to cancer mainly because it:
questions.explanation: Ionization can cause mutations by breaking or modifying DNA strands.

questions.text: Which experiment demonstrated mutation caused by radiation?

options.A: Discovery of the DNA double helix

questions.explanation: Hermann Muller demonstrated radiation-induced mutations using fruit flies in 1927.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an X-ray–based modality?
questions.explanation: MRI uses magnetic fields and radio waves, not X-rays.

questions.text: Fluoroscopy differs from conventional X-ray imaging because it:
questions.explanation: Fluoroscopy provides continuous real-time imaging, unlike static X-ray images.

questions.text: Angiography is primarily used to visualize:
questions.explanation: Angiography visualizes blood vessels, usually using contrast agents.

questions.text: Computed Tomography differs from standard X-ray imaging because it:
questions.explanation: CT reconstructs cross-sectional slices from multiple X-ray projections.

questions.text: X-ray generation in tubes is mainly based on:
questions.explanation: Electrons decelerating near nuclei produce Bremsstrahlung, while shell transitions produce characteristic radiation.

questions.text: Bremsstrahlung radiation occurs when:

options.C: An electron is decelerated near a nucleus

questions.explanation: Bremsstrahlung arises from deceleration of electrons in the electric field of atomic nuclei.

questions.text: Characteristic radiation depends mainly on:
questions.explanation: Characteristic X-ray energies are specific to the atomic structure of the anode material.

questions.text: Why do modern X-ray tubes use rotating anodes?
questions.explanation: Rotating anodes distribute heat over a larger surface, reducing wear.

questions.text: Which interaction is ionizing and dominant at low X-ray energies?
questions.explanation: Photoelectric absorption transfers all photon energy to electrons, causing ionization.

questions.text: Photoelectric absorption strength mainly increases with:
questions.explanation: Denser materials (like bone) absorb more X-rays via the photoelectric effect.

questions.text: Why do bones appear brighter than soft tissue in X-ray images?
questions.explanation: Bones absorb more X-rays, so fewer photons reach the detector, making them appear bright.

questions.text: Traditional X-ray films work because X-rays:
questions.explanation: X-rays expose photographic film in a similar way to visible light.

questions.text: Image intensifiers improve image quality mainly by:
questions.explanation: Image intensifiers convert X-rays to light and amplify the signal for better visibility.

questions.text: In indirect flat-panel detectors:

options.A: X-rays are directly converted into charge
options.B: X-rays are converted into visible light first

questions.explanation: Indirect detectors use a scintillator to convert X-rays into visible light before detection.

questions.text: Energy-integrating detectors measure:
questions.explanation: EIDs sum the total energy deposited by all photons during an exposure.

questions.text: A key advantage of photon-counting detectors is:
questions.explanation: Photon-counting detectors measure individual photon energies, enabling spectral imaging.

questions.text: Photon-counting CT can best be compared to:
questions.explanation: Like color photography, photon-counting CT distinguishes information based on energy.

questions.text: Phase-contrast X-ray imaging exploits differences in:
questions.explanation: Phase-contrast imaging measures changes in the phase of X-rays caused by different materials.

questions.text: Classic phase-contrast methods traditionally required:
questions.explanation: Early phase-contrast imaging required highly coherent, monochromatic synchrotron X-rays.

questions.text: Dark-field X-ray imaging is mainly sensitive to:
questions.explanation: Dark-field imaging detects ultra-small-angle scattering caused by microstructures.
